dict.string:
{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1404\cocoasubrtf470 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Lato-Regular;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;} \deftab720 \pard\pardeftab720\partightenfactor0
\f0\fs26 \cf0 Now you\'92ve learned the basics of Scratch (and if you haven\'92t, check out the Beginner Scratch Sushi Cards) and made your first Scratch game. In this series you\'92re going to learn a few more cool tricks and make one of my favourite Scratch projects: It draws colourful patterns and, if you set it up right, can be really cool to watch.\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ It all relies on the \b pen \b0 tool, which is controlled by blocks in the \b pen \b0 group. These blocks draw a line behind the centre of a sprite as it moves. You\'92re going to learn to use it now!\ \ Start a new Scratch file, select the Scratch Cat \b sprite \b0 and drag in a few of the blocks you\'92re familiar with from the beginner cards, until it looks like this:}

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1404\cocoasubrtf470 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Lato-Regular;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;} \deftab720 \pard\pardeftab720\partightenfactor0
\f0\fs26 \cf0 If you can see the lines behind the cat then the pen is working and you can start making it draw really cool patterns!\ \ First, you should get rid of the cat! It\'92s getting in the way of the drawing! Just add a \'93hide\'94 block from \b looks \b0 to the start of the program and it\'92ll disappear.\ \ }

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1404\cocoasubrtf470 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Lato-Regular;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;} \deftab720 \pard\pardeftab720\partightenfactor0
\f0\fs26 \cf0 Now click the green flag to run the program a few times and see what happens! You\'92ll notice two things: It always starts by drawing a line into the middle of the \b stage and i \b0 t doesn\'92t stop at the edge . \ \ The first is because the first \b motion \b0 block that runs after the \'93pen down\'94 is \'93go to x: 0 y: 0\'94. You can fix this just by moving the \'93go to x: 0 y: 0\'94 block before the \'93pen down\'94 block and adding, from \b pen \b0 , a \'93pen up\'94 block right at the start of your code.\ \ The second is because you haven\'92t yet told it what it\'92s checking, so the answer will never be true. Basically, right now, it\'92s working like a \'93forever\'94 loop.}

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1404\cocoasubrtf470 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Lato-Regular;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;} \deftab720 \pard\pardeftab720\partightenfactor0
\f0\fs26 \cf0 When you run the program now you\'92ll see that it has turned into a circle drawing program! At least it stays on the \b stage \b0 ! The problem here is that those 15 degree turns eventually add up to 360 and you turn a full circle. What needs to happen is that you take slightly longer steps each time, so you spiral out. For this, you\'92re going to need a \b variable \b0 .\ \ You\'92ve seen \b variables \b0 before, in the Beginner series. They\'92re basically labeled places to store numbers that you care about. You can create them in the \b data \b0 blocks category and then find their associated blocks there too.\ \ Make a \b variable \b0 called \'93steps\'94 and use its value instead of the 5 in \'93move 5 steps\'94, then add \'93set steps to 0\'94 at the start of your program and \'93change steps by 1\'94 as part of your loop (does it matter where you put it?). }

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1404\cocoasubrtf470 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Lato-Regular;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;} \deftab720 \pard\pardeftab720\partightenfactor0
\f0\fs26 \cf0 Once you\'92ve got Scratch asking a question, you need it to remember the answer! It turns out that Scratch has a special \b variable \b0 , called \'93answer\'94, where it puts the most recent answer it\'92s received. You can find it among the \b sensing \b0 blocks. Using a \b data \b0 \'93set to \'94 block, take the value from \'93answer\'94 and give it to \'93increase\'94 like so:}

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1404\cocoasubrtf470 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Lato-Regular;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;} \deftab720 \pard\pardeftab720\partightenfactor0
\f0\fs26 \cf0 Ok, this is getting pretty cool, but it\'92s a bit of a headache to have to edit your code every time you want to see a different pattern. Wouldn\'92t it be good to get the program to ask you for them? You can do that!\ \ First, create \b variables \b0 in \b data \b0 for \'93degrees\'94 and \'93increase\'94 and add them to your code like this:}

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1404\cocoasubrtf470 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Lato-Regular;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;} \deftab720 \pard\pardeftab720\partightenfactor0
\f0\fs26 \cf0 Time to add colour! Right now, your line is one colour, but the \b pen \b0 has blocks that can change its colour. With the right \b operator \b0 blocks, you can change it randomly.\ \ The colour changing block you\'92re looking for is \'93change pen color by \'94:\ }

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1404\cocoasubrtf470 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Lato-Regular;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;} \deftab720 \pard\pardeftab720\partightenfactor0
\f0\fs26 \cf0 If you run that, you\'92ll find that the program does draw randomly, but only once. Why do you think that is?\ \ \ It\'92s because the loop only runs until it reaches the edge of the \b stage \b0 . You need \i another \i0 loop, that runs forever (so a \'93forever\'94 block then!) outside the current one to keep it going over and over! Just drag one out of \b control \b0 and wrap your code in it.}

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1404\cocoasubrtf470 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Lato-Regular;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;} \deftab720 \pard\pardeftab720\partightenfactor0
\f0\fs26 \cf0 Now you\'92ve really got something awesome to look at! However, you may notice that, every now and then, the computer draws something that looks pretty\'85 bad. This is because some numbers for some of those variables are just bad choices, and some \i combinations of those numbers \i0 are also bad choices.\ \ Do you remember a few cards back when I told you to write down some of your favourite values for \'93increase\'94 and \'93degrees\'94, the ones that gave the best looking pictures? If not, don\'92t worry, you can just watch the random program run for a while and write down the combinations that give great results.\ \ You\'92re going to teach Scratch those combinations of values, so it can use them to make nothing but awesome pictures!\ \ To do this, you\'92ll need a \b list \b0 . You\'92ll find them with \b variables \b0 , under \b data \b0 . Just like you did with the variables, you\'92ll need to create your list.}

{\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\cocoartf1404\cocoasubrtf470 {\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 LeagueGothic-Regular;\f1\fnil\fcharset0 Lato-Regular;} {\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;} \deftab720 \pard\pardeftab720\partightenfactor0
\f0\fs34 \cf0 If you want to understand what\'92s going on \f1\fs26 \ Imagine your lists only have two pairs of values on them. This is what happens:\
\fs20 \ 1. Set \i counter \i0 to 0\ 2. Start the \i forever loop\
\i0 3. Check \i if \i0 \i counter \i0 (0) is the same as the length of \i Increase List \i0 (2). It isn\'92t\ 4. Change \i counter \i0 by 1. Now \i counter \i0 = 1\ 5. Set \i steps \i0 to 0\ 6. Get the get the item at position \i counter \i0 (1) in the \i Increase \i0 \i List \i0 and put it in \i increase\
\i0 7. Get the get the item at position \i counter \i0 (1) in the \i Degrees \i0 \i List \i0 and put it in \i degrees\
\i0 8. Do all the stuff related to drawing the patterns\ 9. Restart the \i forever loop\
\i0 10. Check \i if \i0 \i counter \i0 (1) is the same as the length of \i Increase List \i0 (2). It isn\'92t\ 11. Change \i counter \i0 by 2. Now \i counter \i0 = 2\ 12. Set \i steps \i0 to 0\ 13. Get the get the item at position \i counter \i0 (2) in the \i Increase \i0 \i List \i0 and put it in \i increase\
\i0 14. \i \i0 Get the get the item at position \i counter \i0 (2) in the \i Degrees \i0 \i List \i0 and put it in \i degrees\
\i0 15. Do all the stuff related to drawing the patterns\ 16. Restart the \i forever loop\
\i0 17. Check \i if \i0 \i counter \i0 (2) is the same as the length of \i Increase List \i0 (2). It is!\ 18. Set \i counter \i0 to 0\ 19. Continue from \b step 4 \b0 of this list, in a never-ending loop!}
